trans-unit.source: Binds the value of a URL segment to a parameter object.

If you implement ASP.NET routing in a Web site, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> object to bind the value of a segment of the requested URL to a database query or command.
You can declare <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> objects in markup for data source controls or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.QueryExtender> control.
A Visual Studio Web site project with source code is available to accompany this topic: [Download](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=168640).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> class.
You use this constructor method to initialize a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> object and set default values.
The properties are initialized to the following values:
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.RouteKey%2A> is set to an empty string ("").
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Name%2A> is set to an empty string.
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Type%2A> is set to <xref:System.TypeCode.Empty>.
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.Direction%2A> is set to <xref:System.Data.ParameterDirection.Input>.
<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Parameter.DefaultValue%2A> is set to `null`.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> class by using the values of the specified instance.
This constructor is used to clone a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter> instance.
An object from which the current instance is initialized.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> class by using the specified name for the parameter and the specified key for route data.
The name of the parameter instance.
The name of the route segment that contains the value for the parameter.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> class by using the specified name and database type for the parameter, and by using the specified key for the route data.
The name of the parameter instance.
The database type of the parameter instance.
The name of the route segment that contains the value for the parameter.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> class by using the specified name and type for the parameter, and by using the specified key for the route data.
The name of the parameter instance.
The type that the parameter represents.
The name of the route segment that contains the value for the parameter.
Returns a duplicate of the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter"></xref> instance.
An object that is a duplicate of the current one.
Evaluates the request URL and returns the value of the parameter.
The current <xref href="System.Web.HttpContext"></xref> instance of the request.
The control that the parameter is bound to.
The current value of the parameter.
Gets or sets the name of the route segment from which to retrieve the value for the route parameter.
When you define a route pattern, you can include segments that serve as placeholders for the actual values in the Web request URL.
You define placeholders by enclosing them in braces ( `{` and `}` ).
For example, a route pattern in the format `blog/{action}/{entry}` contains placeholders named `action` and `entry`.

To retrieve the value of a placeholder, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.RouteKey%2A> property to the name of the placeholder and call the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.RouteParameter.Evaluate%2A> method.
The name of the route segment that contains the value for the parameter.
